title: I don't care how well you end up doing or how good your stats are...
body:
If you pick some dumb shit that doesn't fit the team comp, and we end up losing, it's your fault. If we desperately need front line control out of top lane but pick GP instead, it's your fault if we end up losing even if you play really well. Having a reasonable win condition is exceedingly important and by picking champs that don't fill the teams needs, you often guarantee that your team has no win condition other than "snowball so hard that comp doesn't matter". Let me tell you, that is not a reliable win condition. No matter how good you are at your champion, betting the match on your entire team snowballing out of control is an incredibly stupid move to make. 

This doesn't just apply to top laners not picking tanks; it can also apply to mid laners not picking champs with adequate range and CC, junglers not picking champs with adequate early pressure potential, adcs not picking champs with adequate dps potential or adequate mobility, and supports picking champs that go against the rest of the teams flow. Picking Zed when your team needs AOE magic damage and CC will probably fuck you. Picking Warwick when the enemy Elise has multiple high kill pressure lanes to gank will probably fuck you. Picking Ezreal or Lucian when the enemy team has 3 tanks will probably fuck you. Picking Soraka when the rest of your team is playing high pressure playmaker champs will probably fuck you.

Disagree. 

1.) The pick order is very important, If i first pick, and your last pick, I get the advantage of picking whatever I want to play, while you have to react, and pick based on the 'comp' of the team? it's pretty unfair. Players who pick last should be given leniency in regards to comp. 

2.) Many players are only good with 3 or 4 champions and sometimes they dont have a 'frontline' pick or a good 'cc' pick.. This isn't their fault, its just the nature of putting 5 random strangers in a game and hoping for the best. You can't blame someone in that way - its not just or fair.

3.) Use your judgement and leave the game if you think its going to go south because of champion picks. That's a personal judgement call you have to make. It's probably the best solution for this problem. 

I would say that pick comp is important - and you should consider it, but if you take a champion in a role, do decently well, have good stats, and you lose? its definitely not your fault because you didn't "pick a tank." That's bullshit.

Don't know about HOTS, but I think mechanics like that wouldn't work too well, due to how much the meta shifts, and Riot doesn't particularly want to enforce or encourage a particular meta. The necessity of a tank, or the amount of CC you need for a comp, is completely relative to what that comp is trying to accomplish. (A Liss/Kennen can easily provide Team engage due to their kits, and not need to be tanky.) 

But that's another reason why we need more communication, if everyone has different opinions on what the comp should look like, your actual composition is going to look like a mess. Also cause I don't think everyone has the same definition of Tank. Sometimes they actually mean a Vanguard with legitimate team engage, other times, they just want someone who doesn't die in 2 seconds.
I just consider this part of the "magic of solo queue." Or ranked in general - its fun to see who's shitty comp will win them the day.

This implies that everyone has a champion pool large enough that they can fit whatever role their team needs them to fill. I think that's an unrealistic expectation. If your top laner isn't comfortable playing tanks then why force him to play one? I can't tell you how many times someone has picked a champion because "it synergized well" only to get complete dominated in lane. Nevermind the whole auto fill issue. If one of my teammates gets auto filled I want them playing their best champion in that role because they're already at a huge disadvantage playing a role they don't play that often.

I do agree with your over arching concepts that people need to communicate more in champion select and need to be more flexible in their picks. There's no reason not to pick a champ that synergized well with your team if you know how to play them. That said, it's unrealistic to expect every person to have at least 1 champion of every class or subclass that they can play in ranked.
